title: Circadian metabolomics from mice and men: Insights for mechanism and medicine

author: Steven A. Brown, Institute of Pharmacology and Toxicology, University of Zurich

segmentation: So thanks very much.
It's a great pleasure to be here.
Speaking to you, I am going to continue on a somewhat human and applied theme, at least initially here to discuss how a circadian clocks might actually play a role in Chrono Pharmaka.
Allergy and medicine.
At this point 4 talks in you figured out that many different aspects of Physiology in mammals are circadian.
I don't think I need to review that further.
You've also figured out.
Ouch that although there's a central Clock in your brain controlling behavior, circadian Clock work is present in all of the cells of your body where it is controlling important processes.
So the two topics I'm going to talk about today one is, how do these clocks affect metabolism?
An in particular metabolomics, the set of all metabolites that you might harvest from a particular matrix, and Secondly, what consequences does this metabolic control have for cancer?
So I, you've guessed from all of the circadian Physiology you've heard about that.
A lot of genes are expressed in circadian fashion.
About 10% in mammals, regardless of what tissue you look at.

That a significant percentage of the proteome is also expressed in circadian fashion.
20% of mouse liver proteins were found to in this particular study to be expressed in circadian fashion.

You might be saying to yourself, of course.
Well sure, it's rhythmic.
I eat rhythmically, I sleep rhythmically.
Why shouldn't the mataba?
Lights be rhythmic as well, so the an certainly 20% of the mouse metabolome is also rhythmic.
But how much of this is actually due to rhythmic food intake or rhythmic sleep?
Or things like that?
Human beings have the advantage over mice that they'll do exactly what you tell them when you tell them so we decided to address these question in a so called constant routine protocol.
These lucky subjects came into the lab were sleep deprived for 40 hours.
Every hour they tonight Isocaloric meal were kept in exactly the same position in the same light, not allowed to move around, and had blood and saliva drawn every hour.
So this is about as constant as you can get.
I can we then harvested blood and saliva and looked at metabolites there.
This being worked primarily by Robert Dolman, a postdoc in the lab.
What we found was once again about 20% of metabolites were expressed in rhythmic fashion in both plasma and in saliva.
Even though these people were not sleeping with mickley, they were deprived of sleep the entire time.
For these 40 hours and they were not eating rhythmically.
They had a meal every hour.
In plasma.
As you can see, the bulk of things that we.
Rhythmic ended up being lipids.
You can see that in this slide here a whole lot of lipid Physiology happening in rhythmic fashion.
In saliva, the bulk of rhythmic things identified were amino acids and this time.
In different phases of the day.
So where do we?
How can we actually bring this directly into a clinically relevant setting?
Certainly not by constant routine protocols.
Breath actually contains a huge richness of metabolites.
When you are breathing out, you are breathing out all sorts of interesting things, and mass spectrometry is now sensitive enough that you can detect this.
So to us if we can somehow optimize some of these things to work in human breath.
Now we can find out an awful lot.
So here are some preliminary results in that fashion.
The human circadian breath metabolome from 3 subjects with hourly resolution and you can see quite clearly that many things are rhythmic.
So you're looking at individual metabolites along horizontal lines in three subjects, and there are subject to subject variations.
What can you do with this this?
That is work together with Robert Anne Leila Tarokh, along with mass spec experts Pablo Martinez, Lausanne Sinew as in the Zenobi lab at the Etihad.
So.
If you do simple principle component analysis, the first thing you can see is that different times are clustering together very nicely.
This suggests that a breath print might give you circadian time of day.
So far we've been a.
To do that in a single time, .2 plus or minus three hours, which is good but not outstanding.
And we are attempting to refine these algorithms further.
So why would we care about circadian time?
One thing you know about drugs is that the context in which they're taking taken matters quite a lot.
An one of these contexts is the time at which they're taking taken.

Mix in mice as well.

We I guess we smear a little bit of food around here so that it smells good and you can see that he comes right up to the detector to help out and we can detect his breath.

You can see.
That it is very nicely dose responsive different injections, amounts of keta mean injected are quite linear.

We do not yet have enough to say whether they become more arrhythmic with increasing grade.
That would be a nice thing if you're a nice hypothesis, but we have no evidence for it at this point.
So if tumors may or may not have actual clocks and all the work you saw from Frances's lab has shown us quite clearly that the host Clock really does matter in terms of tumor growth.
We end up with the question of are these differences relevant for cancer progression?
Falsie showed you a variety of models in which by getting rid of the central Clock in the brain or by reinforcing it by meal timing, you can enhance or reduce tumor growth.
If tumors have clocks or don't, the question is, will tumors without clocks grow differently than tumors?
So that do have clocks.
So the experiment in this case is to take an actual tumor line that has a Clock and now dominantly negatively disrupt that Clock with a small interfering RNA.
So the same line that did have a Clock now doesn't, and we can take a look to see whether this tumor will grow differently.
The answer to our surprise is it depends on how you knock down the Clock.
Here you're looking at two different ways of knocking down clocks in lines, both of which results in a cell line that is completely arrhythmic in one place.
Getting rid of bmal.
This was the positive factor that is activating transcription of Clock genes mentioned in akims talk.
The other, a double knockdown of per one and per two.
Which are components of repressors which are oppressing the same thing that be?
Mel is activating so two different ways of knocking down the Clock and what you can see.
In the case of Bmal knock down, there was absolutely no difference in the growth of these tumors.
In the case of knocking down per one and per two, there was a very clear difference.
So the question is, well, why is there this big difference?
In one case?
Nothing in another case, something our hypothesis was that maybe in some cases you can compensate for o'clock by systemically driving it by external cues.
Just.
Before I go there, I'll show you breaking this Clock in two ways.
Again, you can see final weight of the tumor between wild type and female knockout.
No difference between wild type and per one per two about a two fold difference.
And why might this be?
So our hypothesis here is that maybe some portions of Clock function can be systemically compensated by rhythmic environment, by rhythmic cues from the central Clock.
Something like this.
This is not as far fetched as it sounds.
Liver specific Clock disruption of Bmal showed it was shown by Benoit conman in this paper that there was indeed some circadian gene expression left that was driven.
So how can we test that hypothesis?
We would have to look in the tumors themselves.
For circadian oscillations or not in vivo in the animal?
So.
The final technique technique I'll introduce you today is in Vivo Lu Manometry.
In this case, you have a dark room with a dark box with a very dark age.
On top of that, there is an infrared detector to detect mouse movement.

A photomultiplier tube to detect light emitted from these tumors that are infected with this luciferase construct, and finally a controllable light in case you want to give this Maus ECU to synchronize its circadian clocks.
So let's start with the rhythmic tumor.

In the actual tumor, as it grows and what you can see is that there is nicely rhythmic bmal luciferase expression, so this tumor clearly has a Clock.
It's clearly nicely synchronized to the Clock of its host.

So now what happens if we use those tumors?
So these tumors don't have a, in theory a Clock at all, because Bmal has been illuminated.
If you look at these tumors, you can see that in the context of arrhythmic host.
The tumor is still showing very nice circadian oscillations.
Which is proof that a host Clock can indeed in some aspects, systemically compensate for the lack of a tumor Clock.
So what this means in terms of implications for human chronobiology?
Is that this is probably a complicated problem.
In order for us to really be able to deliver a cures that will help people.
In the worst case scenario, it would be a four o'clock problem.
In the one case you have a master Clock in the Super chiasmatic nucleus determining behavior, you can reinforce that or not and this would help send systemic cues.
In the liver you have clocks affecting circadian drug metabolism, affecting the pharmacokinetics of the drugs you're giving.
In the tumor itself, you have clocks that can be present or broken during the course of making cancer, which can or cannot synchronize the cell cycle, and perhaps restrain tumor growth.
And finally not addressed at all here, but logical to imagine in the stroma surrounding the tumor clocks might be important for circadian chrono toxicity.
So in short, I hope I've shown you here.
That's Chrono Pharmacology is indeed a relevant question.
Inhuman treatment, and in the case of cancer that modulating these clocks in the way that clinicians like Francis are doing, might actually someday bring durable benefits to patients.
